<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 448, 782, 464]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 464, 322, 479]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 479, 504, 495]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 495, 504, 510]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 510, 380, 525]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 540, 910, 571]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions in the space provided. If additional space is required, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet. The question number(s) must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 570, 910, 600]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 600, 598, 615]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 615, 608, 630]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 644, 608, 660]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 660, 757, 675]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 675, 440, 690]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 125]]<|/det|>
The masses of a certain variety of plums are known to have standard deviation \(13.2 \text{g}\). A random sample of 200 of these plums is taken and the mean mass of the plums in the sample is found to be \(62.3 \text{g}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 135, 156, 153]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 135, 692, 153]]<|/det|>

<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
The independent random variables \(X\) and \(Y\) have the distributions N(9.2, 12.1) and N(3.0, 8.6) respectively. Find \(\mathrm{P}(X > 3Y)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 87, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 155]]<|/det|>
At factory \(A\) the mean number of accidents per year is 32. At factory \(B\) the records of numbers of accidents before 2018 have been lost, but the number of accidents during 2018 was 21. It is known that the number of accidents per year can be well modelled by a Poisson distribution. Use an approximating distribution to test at the \(2\%\) significance level whether the mean number of accidents at factory \(B\) is less than at factory \(A\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 135, 920, 153]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
The lifetimes, \(X\) hours, of a random sample of 50 batteries of a certain kind were found. The results are summarised by \(\Sigma x = 420\) and \(\Sigma x^2 = 27 530\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 120, 156, 139]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 120, 920, 155]]<|/det|>
Calculate an unbiased estimate of the population mean of \(X\) and show that an unbiased estimate of the population variance is 490, correct to 3 significant figures.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 135, 920, 154]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 73, 153, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
The lifetimes of a further large sample of \(n\) batteries of this kind were noted, and the sample mean, \(\overline{X}\), was found. Use your estimates from part (i) to find the value of \(n\) such that \(\mathrm{P}(\overline{X} > 5) = 0.9377\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 106, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 155]]<|/det|>
The time taken by volunteers to complete a certain task is normally distributed. In the past the time, in minutes, has had mean 91.4 and standard deviation 6.4. A new, similar task is introduced and the times, \(t\) minutes, taken by a random sample of 6 volunteers to complete the new task are summarised by \(\Sigma t = 568.5\). Andrea plans to carry out a test, at the \(5\%\) significance level, of whether the mean time for the new task is different from the mean time for the old task.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 166, 156, 184]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 166, 579, 184]]<|/det|>
Give a reason why Andrea should use a two-tail test.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 166, 920, 184]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 375, 151, 394]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 375, 920, 410]]<|/det|>
State the probability that a Type I error is made, and explain the meaning of a Type I error in this context.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 392, 920, 410]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 751, 92]]<|/det|>
You may assume that the times taken for the new task are normally distributed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 104, 153, 123]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 104, 608, 123]]<|/det|>
Stating another necessary assumption, carry out the test.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 104, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
<mark>[7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[349, 87, 687, 234]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 253, 620, 274]]<|/det|>
A random variable \(X\) has probability density function given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[358, 276, 638, 322]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{f}(x) = \left\{ \begin{array}{ll}(\sqrt{2})\cos x & 0\leqslant x\leqslant \frac{1}{4}\pi ,\\ 0 & \mathrm{otherwise}, \end{array} \right.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 325, 320, 344]]<|/det|>
as shown in the diagram.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 358, 156, 376]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 356, 291, 376]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 358, 920, 376]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 636, 143, 653]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 636, 336, 655]]<|/det|>
